Authors:
yan wang, Jean-Marc Moncalvo, Matt Stata, wei wang, Jason
E. stajich, merlin white
Title:
Comparative genomics reveals the core gene toolbox for the
fungus-insect symbiosis
Abstract:
Modern genomics has shed light on many entomopathogenic
fungi and expanded our knowledge widely, however, little is known about
the genomic features of the insect-commensal fungi. Harpellales are
obligate commensals living in the digestive tracts of disease-bearing
insects (black flies, midges, and mosquitoes). In this study, we produce
and annotate whole-genome sequences of nine Harpellales taxa and conduct
the first comparative analyses to infer the genomic diversity within
Harpellales. The genomes of the insect gut fungi are featured with low
GC content (26-37%) and large genome size variation (25-102 Mb). Further
comparisons with insect-pathogenic fungi from both Ascomycota and
Zoopagomycota, as well as free-living relatives (as negative control),
help identify a gene toolbox that is unique to the fungus-insect
symbiosis. The results not only narrow the genomic scope of
fungus-insect interactions from several thousands to eight core players,
but also distinguish host-invasion strategies employed by insect
pathogens and commensals. The genomic content suggests that insect
commensal fungi mostly rely on adhesion protein anchors that target
digestive system, while emtomopathogenic fungi have higher numbers of
transmembrane helices, singal peptides, and pathogen-host interaction
(PHI) genes across the whole genome and enrich genes as well as
functional domains to inactivate the host inflammation system and
suppress the host defense. Phylogenomic analyses reveal that genome
sizes of Harpellales fungi vary among lineages with an integer multiple
pattern, which implies that ancient genome duplications may have
occurred within the gut of insects.
